response_text:
{
  "conversation": [
    {
      "turn_id": 1,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H-01:05",
      "text": "Hello, I’m your nurse here in the Emergency Department. I see you just came from dialysis because they were worried about your blood pressure and a positive blood culture. How are you feeling right now—any dizziness, shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, or chills?",
      "evidence_eids": ["ADM#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 2,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H-01:03",
      "text": "I feel a little tired, but that’s how I usually feel after dialysis. No chest pain or trouble breathing. I don’t feel feverish. I did have chills at dialysis the other day, but not right now. My blood pressure is always kind of low, they tell me.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 3,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H-01:00",
      "text": "Thanks for telling me. The triage vitals show your blood pressure is on the low side, but that may be your baseline. The doctors are also concerned about that positive blood culture from dialysis, so they’ve started IV antibiotics here. I’m going to put you on the monitor and get some blood work while we wait for the ICU team to see you.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "PHARM#000001", "PHARM#000008"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 4,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H-00:45",
      "text": "Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents. I’ve reviewed your chart: you have HIV, end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis through a left subclavian catheter, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia. You were sent in because your blood cultures from dialysis grew bacteria and your blood pressure has been low. Can you walk me through what happened at dialysis over the last few days?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001", "DX#000001", "DX#000002", "DX#000003", "DX#000005", "DX#000009"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 5,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H-00:42",
      "text": "A couple of days ago during dialysis I got really cold and sweaty. They took some blood cultures and gave me an antibiotic through the machine. Then they called me back because the culture was positive, and today during dialysis my pressure dropped again, but they finished the treatment. They told me to come here.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 6,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H-00:38",
      "text": "That matches what we have. The culture from dialysis showed gram-positive cocci in clusters, which is often a staph-type bacteria, and you received cefazolin and vancomycin there. Here in the ED you’ve gotten another broad-spectrum antibiotic. Your blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s systolic, which may be your baseline, but we’re being cautious because of the positive culture and your HIV. We’re going to admit you to the ICU for close monitoring and IV antibiotics.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000001", "DX#000003", "PHARM#000008"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 7,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H-00:36",
      "text": "ICU? Am I that sick? I don’t feel that bad, just tired and a little lightheaded like after dialysis.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 8,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H-00:34",
      "text": "We’re not seeing signs of severe infection right now—no fever, your exam is reassuring, and your chest X-ray doesn’t show pneumonia. But with your low blood pressure, positive blood culture, and HIV, we want to watch you closely. In the ICU we can monitor your blood pressure continuously, give fluids carefully since you’re on dialysis, and adjust your antibiotics. If everything stays stable, we can move you out quickly.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001", "DX#000001", "DX#000002", "DX#000003"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 9,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H-00:32",
      "text": "Okay, as long as someone explains what’s going on. My pressure is always low, they tell me at dialysis it’s in the 70s or 80s sometimes.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 10,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H-00:30",
      "text": "Your nephrologist confirmed that your usual systolic blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s, especially around dialysis, so that helps us interpret today’s numbers. We’ll still give you a small amount of IV fluid to see if that helps and keep an eye on your labs and lactate. If your blood pressure and symptoms stay at your baseline, that’s reassuring.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RX#000011"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 11,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "H+00:05",
      "text": "I’m the ICU attending. I’ve reviewed your ED course and your history of HIV, ESRD on hemodialysis, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia. Your blood pressure is low but consistent with your reported baseline, and your lactate has improved after fluids. We’re going to continue IV vancomycin to treat the staph from your line and repeat blood cultures to make sure the infection is clearing.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000001", "DX#000002", "DX#000003", "DX#000005", "DX#000009", "PHARM#000008", "LAB#000027", "MICRO#000002"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 12,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:07",
      "text": "Will you have to take out my dialysis catheter because of the infection?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 13,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "H+00:09",
      "text": "Right now, the plan from the nephrology team is to treat through the infection with IV vancomycin given with dialysis for about two weeks, rather than removing the catheter immediately. We’ll watch your repeat blood cultures; if they stay negative and you remain stable, we can keep the line. If cultures stayed positive or you got sicker, we’d reconsider removing it.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "MICRO#000002"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 14,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:11",
      "text": "Okay. I also get this sharp pain on the right side of my face and over my eye sometimes. It’s been there before from shingles, they said. It’s not too bad right now.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000005"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 15,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "H+00:13",
      "text": "That sounds like your trigeminal neuralgia from prior shingles. We’ll continue your pain medicines like oxycodone as needed and gabapentin, and we’ll keep you on valacyclovir as you were taking at home.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "PHARM#000005", "PHARM#000007", "PHARM#000018", "RX#000018", "RX#000014", "RX#000008"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 16,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H+00:20",
      "text": "We’re getting you settled in the ICU now. You’re on the heart monitor and blood pressure cuff. If you feel more lightheaded, short of breath, or have chest pain, please call right away. I’ll also be giving your regular HIV and dialysis-related medications as ordered.",
      "evidence_eids": ["ICU#000001", "PHARM#000004", "PHARM#000009", "PHARM#000011", "PHARM#000012", "PHARM#000013", "PHARM#000015", "PHARM#000017", "PHARM#000018"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 17,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:22",
      "text": "Thank you. I usually feel dizzy and short of breath after dialysis until the next day, so I’ll let you know if it’s worse than usual.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 18,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:30",
      "text": "We’ve reviewed your morning labs. Your white blood cell count is low at 2.9, and your platelets are around 98, which is similar to your prior labs and likely related to your HIV. Your kidney numbers are high as expected with ESRD, and your potassium is mildly elevated at 5.4. Your lactate is normal at 1.7, which is reassuring against severe sepsis.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000007", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000021", "LAB#000022", "LAB#000024", "LAB#000027", "DX#000002", "DX#000011", "DX#000012", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 19,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:32",
      "text": "So the infection isn’t making my blood bad right now?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 20,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:34",
      "text": "Your blood counts haven’t dropped suddenly, and you don’t have a high white count or fever. That, plus the normal lactate and clear chest X-ray, makes a severe bloodstream infection less likely at this moment. We still think the positive culture from your line is real, so we’re treating it with vancomycin and repeating blood cultures to be safe.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000008", "LAB#000027", "RAD#000001", "MICRO#000002", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 21,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:36",
      "text": "Alright. I just don’t want to end up on a breathing machine or something.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 22,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:40",
      "text": "Right now your oxygen level is good on room air, your lungs sound clear, and your chest X-ray doesn’t show any pneumonia. We have no indication that you’ll need a breathing machine, and we’ll keep monitoring you closely.",
      "evidence_eids": ["RAD#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 23,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:30",
      "text": "I’m here to draw some more blood for your morning labs—checking your blood counts, kidney function, and electrolytes again. This helps the team see how you’re doing overnight.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000013", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000022", "LAB#000024"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 24,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:32",
      "text": "Okay. I feel about the same, maybe a little tired. No new pain.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 25,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 04:10",
      "text": "Your new labs are back. Your potassium is 5.4, which is a bit high, and your kidney numbers are up, which we expect between dialysis sessions. We’re going to give you a medication by mouth called Kayexalate to help bring the potassium down while we coordinate your next dialysis.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000022", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000024", "PHARM#000021", "RX#000022", "DX#000015", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 26,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 04:12",
      "text": "Is that why I feel a little funny in my chest sometimes?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 27,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 04:15",
      "text": "High potassium can affect the heart, but your current level is only mildly elevated. We’re treating it early to prevent problems. We’re also watching your heart rhythm on the monitor because you have a history of atrial fibrillation.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000022", "DX#000009", "DX#000015", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 28,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:45",
      "text": "This morning your potassium spiked higher on a repeat lab—up to 7.9—so we treated that urgently and rechecked it. The follow-up labs show it has come back down to around 5.1 and then 4.1 later in the evening, which is much safer.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000039", "LAB#000048", "LAB#000067", "DX#000015", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 29,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:47",
      "text": "Wow, that sounds scary. I did feel my heart racing earlier.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 30,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:50",
      "text": "You did go into a fast heart rhythm—atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. We gave you IV diltiazem to slow your heart rate and then started you on diltiazem pills four times a day. Your heart rate has come down nicely.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000009", "PHARM#000022", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000023", "RX#000025", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 31,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:52",
      "text": "Is that a new medicine I’ll have to keep taking at home?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 32,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:55",
      "text": "Yes. The diltiazem tablets are new for you, and you’ll continue them after discharge to help keep your heart rate controlled. We’ll include it in your discharge prescriptions and instructions.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000024", "RX#000025", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 33,
      "speaker": "CONSULT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 12:10",
      "text": "I’m from the nephrology team. We’re following you for your end-stage renal disease and the line infection. You’ll continue your usual Monday-Wednesday-Friday dialysis schedule, and we’ll give vancomycin with dialysis for about 11 more days to complete a two-week course. We’ll also be careful not to remove too much fluid during dialysis, since aggressive fluid removal seems to drop your blood pressure and make you feel dizzy and short of breath.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "DX#000001", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "RX#000015", "RX#000027", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 34,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 12:12",
      "text": "Yes, when they take off a lot of fluid I feel awful afterward. So you’ll tell them to go easier next time?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 35,
      "speaker": "CONSULT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 12:14",
      "text": "Exactly. We’ll recommend smaller volume removal at your next dialysis session to help keep your blood pressure from dropping so much and reduce your symptoms.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "DX#000007", "DX#000008", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 36,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:20",
      "text": "Your repeat blood cultures drawn here have shown no growth so far, which is a good sign that the infection is under control. You’ve remained afebrile, your blood pressure is at your baseline, and you’re walking around without dizziness.",
      "evidence_eids": ["MICRO#000002", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 37,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:22",
      "text": "That’s good to hear. When do you think I can go home?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 38,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:30",
      "text": "Given your stable blood pressure, controlled heart rate, improving potassium, and negative follow-up blood cultures, we’re planning to discharge you later today with home health services. You’ll continue to receive IV vancomycin at dialysis, and we’ll send prescriptions for your HIV medications, dialysis-related meds, and the new diltiazem.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000039", "LAB#000048", "LAB#000067", "PHARM#000025", "RX#000027", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000025", "DS#000001", "ADM#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 39,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:32",
      "text": "I just moved here and don’t really have doctors yet. How will I get follow-up for my HIV and kidneys?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 40,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:40",
      "text": "We’re arranging follow-up for you. You’ll need to see a new primary care doctor and an HIV specialist within the next week, and also follow up with your renal doctor. We’ll give you phone numbers to call to schedule those appointments, and we’re also giving you refills for your HIV medications, valacyclovir, dialysis-related meds like cinacalcet and sevelamer, and your prophylactic Bactrim.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RX#000003", "RX#000004", "RX#000006", "RX#000007", "RX#000008", "RX#000009", "RX#000010", "RX#000017"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 41,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:42",
      "text": "I haven’t been great about taking my HIV meds lately. I didn’t always have a place to get them. Is that going to hurt me?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 42,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:50",
      "text": "Your HIV labs show a low CD4 count and a high viral load, which means your immune system is quite weak right now. That increases your risk of infections like this line infection. It’s very important to restart and stay on your HIV medications consistently. We’re concerned about your prognosis if the virus stays uncontrolled, so we’re emphasizing close follow-up with an HIV specialist.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000003", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 43,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:52",
      "text": "I understand. I’ll try to keep those appointments and take the meds like you say.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 44,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 17:20",
      "text": "I’m going over your discharge instructions. You’re going home with visiting nurse services. You’ll keep your regular dialysis schedule, and they’ll give you vancomycin through your line at dialysis for the next 11 days. Take diltiazem four times a day for your heart rate, and continue your HIV meds, valacyclovir, sevelamer, cinacalcet, aspirin, Bactrim on Monday-Wednesday-Friday, docusate, and folic acid as prescribed. Call your doctors or come back if you get fever, chills, worsening dizziness, chest pain, or trouble breathing.",
      "evidence_eids": ["ADM#000001", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000025", "RX#000002", "RX#000003", "RX#000004", "RX#000005", "RX#000006", "RX#000007", "RX#000008", "RX#000009", "RX#000010", "RX#000017", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 45,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 17:25",
      "text": "Thank you for explaining everything. I’ll make sure to talk to my dialysis doctors about my low blood pressure too.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    }
  ],
  "end_of_admission_summary": {
    "relative_discharge_time": "H+53:41",
    "one_paragraph_summary": "During this admission, a middle-aged woman with HIV, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis via a left subclavian catheter, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia was admitted from the emergency department to the ICU for evaluation of hypotension in the setting of a positive blood culture from her dialysis unit showing coagulase-negative staphylococcus, likely catheter-related. She was hemodynamically borderline but consistent with her low baseline blood pressure, afebrile, and without clear source of sepsis; chest X-ray showed no acute pulmonary process. Initial labs showed ESRD-level azotemia, mild hyperkalemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, macrocytosis, and normal lactate. She received cautious IV fluids with improvement in lactate, and was treated with IV vancomycin, with a plan to continue dosing via hemodialysis for a total of about two weeks. During the stay she developed significant hyperkalemia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, managed with potassium-lowering therapy and IV then oral diltiazem, with subsequent normalization of potassium and rate control. Repeat blood cultures showed no growth, and she remained clinically stable. She was discharged home with services, to continue vancomycin at dialysis, resume and adhere to her antiretroviral and prophylactic regimens, and follow closely with nephrology, HIV/ID, and primary care.",
    "problem_list": [
      {
        "problem": "Hypotension in the setting of recent dialysis and positive blood culture",
        "status_at_discharge": "Hemodynamically stable at her low baseline blood pressure after small-volume IV fluids; no evidence of progressive sepsis, lactate normalized, and she was ambulatory without dizziness.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DS#000001", "RX#000011", "LAB#000027", "RAD#000001", "ADM#000001"]
      },
      {
        "problem": "Catheter-associated bloodstream infection with coagulase-negative Staphylococcus",
        "status_at_discharge": "Clinically improved, afebrile, with follow-up blood cultures showing no growth; plan to complete a two-week course of IV vancomycin dosed with hemodialysis without immediate catheter removal.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000001", "DX#000004", "DX#000006", "MICRO#000002", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "RX#000015", "RX#000027", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "problem": "End-stage renal disease on hemodialysis with hyperkalemia",
        "status_at_discharge": "Remained dialysis-dependent with elevated creatinine and BUN; episode of severe hyperkalemia (K up to 7.9) treated medically and with dialysis, with potassium improved to near-normal range by discharge; advised to continue MWF dialysis with reduced ultrafiltration.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000002", "DX#000015", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000022", "LAB#000024", "LAB#000031", "LAB#000036", "LAB#000039", "LAB#000044", "LAB#000050", "LAB#000067", "PHARM#000021", "RX#000022", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "problem": "Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response",
        "status_at_discharge": "Rate controlled after IV diltiazem and transition to oral diltiazem 30 mg QID; discharged on oral diltiazem with instructions to continue.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000009", "PHARM#000022", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000023", "RX#000025", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "problem": "Advanced HIV infection with leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and macrocytosis",
        "status_at_discharge": "Immunocompromised with low CD4 and high viral load; leukopenia and thrombocytopenia stable compared with prior values; macrocytosis with normal folate on replacement. Discharged on a full antiretroviral regimen and prophylactic medications with strong recommendation for close HIV/ID follow-up.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000003", "DX#000010", "DX#000011", "DX#000012", "DX#000013", "LAB#000003", "LAB#000005", "LAB#000006", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000025", "LAB#000056", "RX#000002", "RX#000003", "RX#000006", "RX#000007", "RX#000008", "RX#000009", "RX#000010", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "problem": "Trigeminal neuralgia and postherpetic neuralgia",
        "status_at_discharge": "Chronic right-sided facial pain attributed to prior VZV; continued on gabapentin, oxycodone as needed, and valacyclovir; pain controlled during admission.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000005", "PHARM#000005", "PHARM#000007", "PHARM#000018", "RX#000014", "RX#000018", "RX#000008", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "problem": "Anemia of chronic kidney disease with macrocytosis",
        "status_at_discharge": "Hematocrit initially elevated, thought to be hemoconcentration, then trended down to values closer to baseline; no evidence of acute bleeding; continued folate supplementation.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000014", "LAB#000001", "LAB#000051", "LAB#000055", "RX#000002", "DS#000001"]
      }
    ],
    "key_tests_and_results": [
      {
        "test": "Portable chest X-ray",
        "result": "No definite acute pulmonary process; left subclavian dual-lumen dialysis catheter in place, subtle hazy opacity at left lung base likely soft tissue, no consolidation, edema, effusion, or pneumothorax.",
        "relative_time": "H-00:39",
        "supporting_eids": ["RAD#000001"]
      },
      {
        "test": "Initial hematology panel",
        "result": "WBC 2.9 K/uL (low), platelets 98 K/uL (low), macrocytosis with MCV 106 fL and elevated MCH; consistent with chronic leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and macrocytosis.",
        "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:24",
        "supporting_eids": ["LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000005", "LAB#000007", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000025"]
      },
      {
        "test": "Initial chemistry panel and lactate",
        "result": "Creatinine 6.7 mg/dL, BUN 35 mg/dL, potassium 5.4 mEq/L, bicarbonate 18 mEq/L, anion gap 23 mEq/L, lactate 1.7 mmol/L; consistent with ESRD, mild hyperkalemia, and mild metabolic acidosis without elevated lactate.",
        "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:24–04:00",
        "supporting_eids": ["LAB#000011", "LAB#000013", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000018", "LAB#000021", "LAB#000022", "LAB#000024", "LAB#000027"]
      },
      {
        "test": "Peak hyperkalemia episode",
        "result": "Potassium rose to 7.9 mEq/L with creatinine 7.9 mg/dL and BUN 44 mg/dL, requiring urgent treatment; subsequent labs showed potassium down to 5.1 and then 4.1 mEq/L with stable sodium and bicarbonate.",
        "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 14:38–20:30",
        "supporting_eids": ["LAB#000031", "LAB#000036", "LAB#000039", "LAB#000044", "LAB#000048", "LAB#000050", "LAB#000060", "LAB#000061", "LAB#000063", "LAB#000067", "LAB#000069"]
      },
      {
        "test": "Blood cultures during admission",
        "result": "Repeat blood culture obtained in hospital showed no growth, supporting clearance of bacteremia under vancomycin therapy.",
        "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 ~15:30 (resulted later)",
        "supporting_eids": ["MICRO#000002", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "test": "Vancomycin levels",
        "result": "Vancomycin level 11.0 ug/mL during therapy, within therapeutic range for continued dosing with hemodialysis.",
        "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 14:38",
        "supporting_eids": ["LAB#000037", "DS#000001"]
      }
    ],
    "treatments_and_meds": [
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Intravenous fluids for hypotension",
        "details": "Received cautious IV crystalloid (0.45% and 0.9% sodium chloride) in the ICU, resulting in improved lactate and stable blood pressure at her low baseline.",
        "supporting_eids": ["RX#000011", "RX#000024", "LAB#000027", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Intravenous vancomycin for catheter-associated bacteremia",
        "details": "Started on IV vancomycin in hospital with dosing coordinated with hemodialysis, with plan to continue 1 g IV at dialysis for approximately 11 additional days after discharge to complete a two-week course.",
        "supporting_eids": ["PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "RX#000015", "RX#000027", "LAB#000037", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Management of hyperkalemia",
        "details": "Treated severe hyperkalemia (K up to 7.9 mEq/L) with oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate) and dialysis, resulting in potassium reduction to near-normal levels.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000015", "LAB#000039", "LAB#000048", "LAB#000067", "PHARM#000021", "RX#000022", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Rate control for atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response",
        "details": "Administered IV diltiazem followed by oral diltiazem 30 mg QID, achieving adequate heart rate control; diltiazem continued as a new chronic medication at discharge.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000009", "PHARM#000022", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000023", "RX#000025", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Chronic hemodialysis management",
        "details": "Maintained on MWF hemodialysis schedule; nephrology recommended reduced ultrafiltration volumes to mitigate dialysis-associated hypotension and symptoms.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000002", "DX#000007", "DX#000008", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Antiretroviral therapy and prophylaxis for HIV",
        "details": "Discharged on atazanavir, lamivudine, ritonavir, tenofovir, and prophylactic sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim, with counseling on adherence and urgent need for HIV/ID follow-up.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000003", "RX#000003", "RX#000006", "RX#000007", "RX#000009", "RX#000010", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Medications for ESRD-related mineral bone disease",
        "details": "Continued cinacalcet and sevelamer carbonate to manage secondary hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia associated with ESRD.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000002", "LAB#000021", "LAB#000034", "LAB#000047", "LAB#000066", "RX#000004", "RX#000017", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "Pain and neuropathy management",
        "details": "Continued gabapentin and PRN oxycodone for trigeminal neuralgia and peripheral neuropathy, along with valacyclovir and erythromycin eye ointment for prior VZV-related ocular involvement.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000005", "DX#000010", "PHARM#000005", "PHARM#000007", "PHARM#000014", "PHARM#000018", "RX#000014", "RX#000018", "RX#000020", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
        "treatment_or_med": "VTE prophylaxis",
        "details": "Received subcutaneous heparin during hospitalization for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis.",
        "supporting_eids": ["PHARM#000002", "RX#000019", "DS#000001"]
      }
    ],
    "disposition": {
      "discharge_location": "Home with home health services and ongoing hemodialysis-based antibiotic therapy",
      "supporting_eids": ["ADM#000001", "DS#000001", "XFER#000006"]
    }
  }
}

{
  "conversation": [

      "turn_id": 1,

      "text": "Hello, I’m your nurse here in the Emergency Department. I see you just came from dialysis because they were worried about your blood pressure and a positive blood culture. How are you feeling right now—any dizziness, shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, or chills?",
      "evidence_eids": ["ADM#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 2,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H-01:03",
      "text": "I feel a little tired, but that’s how I usually feel after dialysis. No chest pain or trouble breathing. I don’t feel feverish. I did have chills at dialysis the other day, but not right now. My blood pressure is always kind of low, they tell me.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 3,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H-01:00",
      "text": "Thanks for telling me. The triage vitals show your blood pressure is on the low side, but that may be your baseline. I’m going to put you on the monitor and get some blood work while we wait for the ICU team to see you.",

    },

      "text": "Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents. Here in the ED you’ve gotten another broad-spectrum antibiotic. Your blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s systolic, which may be your baseline, but we’re being cautious because of the positive culture and your HIV. We’re going to admit you to the ICU for close monitoring and IV antibiotics.",

    {

But with your low blood pressure, positive blood culture, and HIV, we want to watch you closely. In the ICU we can monitor your blood pressure continuously, give fluids carefully since you’re on dialysis, and adjust your antibiotics. If everything stays stable, we can move you out quickly.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001", "DX#000001", "DX#000002", "DX#000003"]

    {
      "turn_id": 9,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",

We’ll still give you a small amount of IV fluid to see if that helps and keep an eye on your labs and lactate. If your blood pressure and symptoms stay at your baseline, that’s reassuring.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RX#000011"]

We’re going to continue IV vancomycin to treat the staph from your line and repeat blood cultures to make sure the infection is clearing.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000001", "DX#000002", "DX#000003", "DX#000005", "DX#000009", "PHARM#000008", "LAB#000027", "MICRO#000002"]

    {

      "text": "Right now, the plan from the nephrology team is to treat through the infection with IV vancomycin given with dialysis for about two weeks, rather than removing the catheter immediately. We’ll watch your repeat blood cultures; if they stay negative and you remain stable, we can keep the line. If cultures stayed positive or you got sicker, we’d reconsider removing it.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "MICRO#000002"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 14,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:11",
      "text": "Okay. I also get this sharp pain on the right side of my face and over my eye sometimes. It’s been there before from shingles, they said. It’s not too bad right now.",

    {

      "speaker": "ATTENDING",

      "text": "That sounds like your trigeminal neuralgia from prior shingles. We’ll continue your pain medicines like oxycodone as needed and gabapentin, and we’ll keep you on valacyclovir as you were taking at home.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "PHARM#000005", "PHARM#000007", "PHARM#000018", "RX#000018", "RX#000014", "RX#000008"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 16,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H+00:20",
      "text": "We’re getting you settled in the ICU now. You’re on the heart monitor and blood pressure cuff. If you feel more lightheaded, short of breath, or have chest pain, please call right away. I’ll also be giving your regular HIV and dialysis-related medications as ordered.",
      "evidence_eids": ["ICU#000001", "PHARM#000004", "PHARM#000009", "PHARM#000011", "PHARM#000012", "PHARM#000013", "PHARM#000015", "PHARM#000017", "PHARM#000018"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 17,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:22",
      "text": "Thank you. I usually feel dizzy and short of breath after dialysis until the next day, so I’ll let you know if it’s worse than usual.",

    {

      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:30",
      "text": "We’ve reviewed your morning labs. Your white blood cell count is low at 2.9, and your platelets are around 98, which is similar to your prior labs and likely related to your HIV. Your kidney numbers are high as expected with ESRD, and your potassium is mildly elevated at 5.4. Your lactate is normal at 1.7, which is reassuring against severe sepsis.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000007", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000021", "LAB#000022", "LAB#000024", "LAB#000027", "DX#000002", "DX#000011", "DX#000012", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 19,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",

    {
      "turn_id": 20,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:34",
      "text": "Your blood counts haven’t dropped suddenly, and you don’t have a high white count or fever. That, plus the normal lactate and clear chest X-ray, makes a severe bloodstream infection less likely at this moment. We still think the positive culture from your line is real, so we’re treating it with vancomycin and repeating blood cultures to be safe.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000008", "LAB#000027", "RAD#000001", "MICRO#000002", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 21,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:36",
      "text": "Alright. I just don’t want to end up on a breathing machine or something.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 22,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 14:40",
      "text": "Right now your oxygen level is good on room air, your lungs sound clear, and your chest X-ray doesn’t show any pneumonia. We have no indication that you’ll need a breathing machine, and we’ll keep monitoring you closely.",
      "evidence_eids": ["RAD#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 23,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:30",
      "text": "I’m here to draw some more blood for your morning labs—checking your blood counts, kidney function, and electrolytes again. This helps the team see how you’re doing overnight.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000013", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000022", "LAB#000024"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 24,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:32",
      "text": "Okay. I feel about the same, maybe a little tired. No new pain.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 25,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 04:10",
      "text": "Your new labs are back. Your potassium is 5.4, which is a bit high, and your kidney numbers are up, which we expect between dialysis sessions. We’re going to give you a medication by mouth called Kayexalate to help bring the potassium down while we coordinate your next dialysis.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000022", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000024", "PHARM#000021", "RX#000022", "DX#000015", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 26,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 04:12",
      "text": "Is that why I feel a little funny in my chest sometimes?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 27,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 04:15",
      "text": "High potassium can affect the heart, but your current level is only mildly elevated. We’re treating it early to prevent problems. We’re also watching your heart rhythm on the monitor because you have a history of atrial fibrillation.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000022", "DX#000009", "DX#000015", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 28,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:45",
      "text": "This morning your potassium spiked higher on a repeat lab—up to 7.9—so we treated that urgently and rechecked it. The follow-up labs show it has come back down to around 5.1 and then 4.1 later in the evening, which is much safer.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000039", "LAB#000048", "LAB#000067", "DX#000015", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 29,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:47",
      "text": "Wow, that sounds scary. I did feel my heart racing earlier.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 30,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:50",
      "text": "You did go into a fast heart rhythm—atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. We gave you IV diltiazem to slow your heart rate and then started you on diltiazem pills four times a day. Your heart rate has come down nicely.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000009", "PHARM#000022", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000023", "RX#000025", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 31,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:52",
      "text": "Is that a new medicine I’ll have to keep taking at home?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 32,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:55",
      "text": "Yes. The diltiazem tablets are new for you, and you’ll continue them after discharge to help keep your heart rate controlled. We’ll include it in your discharge prescriptions and instructions.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000024", "RX#000025", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 33,
      "speaker": "CONSULT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 12:10",
      "text": "I’m from the nephrology team. We’re following you for your end-stage renal disease and the line infection. You’ll continue your usual Monday-Wednesday-Friday dialysis schedule, and we’ll give vancomycin with dialysis for about 11 more days to complete a two-week course. We’ll also be careful not to remove too much fluid during dialysis, since aggressive fluid removal seems to drop your blood pressure and make you feel dizzy and short of breath.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "DX#000001", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "RX#000015", "RX#000027", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 34,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 12:12",
      "text": "Yes, when they take off a lot of fluid I feel awful afterward. So you’ll tell them to go easier next time?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 35,
      "speaker": "CONSULT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 12:14",
      "text": "Exactly. We’ll recommend smaller volume removal at your next dialysis session to help keep your blood pressure from dropping so much and reduce your symptoms.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "DX#000007", "DX#000008", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 36,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:20",
      "text": "Your repeat blood cultures drawn here have shown no growth so far, which is a good sign that the infection is under control. You’ve remained afebrile, your blood pressure is at your baseline, and you’re walking around without dizziness.",
      "evidence_eids": ["MICRO#000002", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 37,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:22",
      "text": "That’s good to hear. When do you think I can go home?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 38,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:30",
      "text": "Given your stable blood pressure, controlled heart rate, improving potassium, and negative follow-up blood cultures, we’re planning to discharge you later today with home health services. You’ll continue to receive IV vancomycin at dialysis, and we’ll send prescriptions for your HIV medications, dialysis-related meds, and the new diltiazem.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000039", "LAB#000048", "LAB#000067", "PHARM#000025", "RX#000027", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000025", "DS#000001", "ADM#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 39,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:32",
      "text": "I just moved here and don’t really have doctors yet. How will I get follow-up for my HIV and kidneys?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 40,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:40",
      "text": "We’re arranging follow-up for you. You’ll need to see a new primary care doctor and an HIV specialist within the next week, and also follow up with your renal doctor. We’ll give you phone numbers to call to schedule those appointments, and we’re also giving you refills for your HIV medications, valacyclovir, dialysis-related meds like cinacalcet and sevelamer, and your prophylactic Bactrim.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RX#000003", "RX#000004", "RX#000006", "RX#000007", "RX#000008", "RX#000009", "RX#000010", "RX#000017"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 41,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:42",
      "text": "I haven’t been great about taking my HIV meds lately. I didn’t always have a place to get them. Is that going to hurt me?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 42,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:50",
      "text": "Your HIV labs show a low CD4 count and a high viral load, which means your immune system is quite weak right now. That increases your risk of infections like this line infection. It’s very important to restart and stay on your HIV medications consistently. We’re concerned about your prognosis if the virus stays uncontrolled, so we’re emphasizing close follow-up with an HIV specialist.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000003", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 43,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 15:52",
      "text": "I understand. I’ll try to keep those appointments and take the meds like you say.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 44,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 17:20",
      "text": "I’m going over your discharge instructions. You’re going home with visiting nurse services. You’ll keep your regular dialysis schedule, and they’ll give you vancomycin through your line at dialysis for the next 11 days. Take diltiazem four times a day for your heart rate, and continue your HIV meds, valacyclovir, sevelamer, cinacalcet, aspirin, Bactrim on Monday-Wednesday-Friday, docusate, and folic acid as prescribed. Call your doctors or come back if you get fever, chills, worsening dizziness, chest pain, or trouble breathing.",
      "evidence_eids": ["ADM#000001", "PHARM#000024", "RX#000025", "RX#000002", "RX#000003", "RX#000004", "RX#000005", "RX#000006", "RX#000007", "RX#000008", "RX#000009", "RX#000010", "RX#000017", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 45,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 17:25",
      "text": "Thank you for explaining everything. I’ll make sure to talk to my dialysis doctors about my low blood pressure too.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    }
  ],
  "end_of_admission_summary": {
    "relative_discharge_time": "H+53:41",
    "one_paragraph_summary": "During this admission, a middle-aged woman with HIV, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis via a left subclavian catheter, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia was admitted from the emergency department to the ICU for evaluation of hypotension in the setting of a positive blood culture from her dialysis unit showing coagulase-negative staphylococcus, likely catheter-related. She was hemodynamically borderline but consistent with her low baseline blood pressure, afebrile, and without clear source of sepsis; chest X-ray showed no acute pulmonary process. Initial labs showed ESRD-level azotemia, mild hyperkalemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, macrocytosis, and normal lactate. She received cautious IV fluids with improvement in lactate, and was treated with IV vancomycin, with a plan to continue dosing via hemodialysis for a total of about two weeks. During the stay she developed significant hyperkalemia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, managed with potassium-lowering therapy and IV then oral diltiazem, with subsequent normalization of potassium and rate control. Repeat blood cultures showed no growth, and she remained clinically stable. She was discharged home with services, to continue vancomycin at dialysis, resume and adhere to her antiretroviral and prophylactic regimens, and follow closely with nephrology, HIV/ID, and primary care.",
    "problem_list": [
      {
        "problem": "Hypotension in the setting of recent dialysis and positive blood culture",
        "status_at_discharge": "Hemodynamically stable at her low baseline blood pressure after small-volume IV fluids; no evidence of progressive sepsis, lactate normalized, and she was ambulatory without dizziness.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DS#000001", "RX#000011", "LAB#000027", "RAD#000001", "ADM#000001"]
      },
      {
        "problem": "Catheter-associated bloodstream infection with coagulase-negative Staphylococcus",
        "status_at_discharge": "Clinically improved, afebrile, with follow-up blood cultures showing no growth; plan to complete a two-week course of IV vancomycin dosed with hemodialysis without immediate catheter removal.",
        "supporting_eids": ["DX#000001", "DX#000004", "DX#000006", "MICRO#000002", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000025", "RX#000015", "RX#000027", "DS#000001"]
      },
      {
